introduction.text: This chapter explores the core components of research methodology including research models, theories, methods, research design, data collection methods, and data analysis. Authored by AASTU, March 2025.

content.text: Part-I Research Methodology, Research Process “Onion”, Philosophy, Approaches, Strategies, Research Possibilities Grid, theoretical/Conceptual framework, Empirical Research (Chapter 4)
Part-II Research Design, Sampling, Data collection methods, Data Analysis, Data Interpretation and Findings (Chapter 5)

contentBlocks.alt: Diagram recapping the research process: Starting points (what, why, matter), Literature review (empirical work, theories), feeding into Research question (What? Why? How?), then Research design, Data collection, Analytic approach. Sidebar shows Justification ('So what') linked to Problem Gap/Hook.

caption.text: Recap of the Research Process by Lauren Maggio & Sebastian Uijtdehaage.

content.text: Ontology + Epistemology = Research philosophy. Philosophy: Researcher's worldview.

contentBlocks.alt: Research Methodology Tree: Roots (Ontology - how we view the world), Trunk (Epistemology - how we should investigate the world), Branches (Methodology - how we should best collect data), Leaves (Methods - details of exactly how we collect data).
Venn diagram showing Knowledge as the intersection of Justification (reasons/evidence for believing), Belief (we think it's true), and Truth (it's true). Notes on Mistaken belief and Denial.

caption.text: Knowledge as a justified true belief. (Thinking Is Power icon)

contentBlocks.alt: Concentric circles representing the Research Onion: Outer layer 'Paradigms', middle 'Methodology', inner 'Methods'.

content.text: Research Philosophy + Research Methodology = Research Paradigm

Flow: Ontology (What is reality?) -> Epistemology (How can I know reality?) -> Theoretical perspective (What approach?) -> Methodology (What procedure?) -> Methods (What tools?) -> Sources (What data?). Adapted from Hay (2002) & Crotty (1998).
If Ontology is about what reality is, what's Epistemology about?

contentBlocks.alt: Detailed Research Onion diagram showing layers: Outer (Positivism, Interpretivism), Inductive/Deductive approaches, Research Strategies (Experiment, Survey, Case study, Grounded Theory, Ethnography, Action Research), Time Horizons (Cross Sectional, Longitudinal), Data Collection Methods (Sampling, Secondary Data, Observation, Interviews).

caption.text: Detailed layers of the research process onion.

content.text: Imagine you're peeling this research onion. What's at the very core?
The Onion Model: Research as an Onion
Layers of the onion represent different aspects of the research process.
Each layer must be considered to develop a comprehensive research approach.
Layers of the Research Onion include:
How the research will be conducted (e.g., case study, experiment).
Tools and processes for data collection and analysis.

Research philosophy refers to the fundamental beliefs and assumptions about the nature of knowledge and how it can be acquired. It influences how researchers approach their studies, interpret data, and understand the world.
Emphasizes observable phenomena and often uses
Focuses on understanding the subjective meaning of social phenomena, typically using
Acknowledges the existence of a reality independent of human perceptions while recognizing our understanding is
If a researcher believes there's one objective truth out there waiting to be discovered, what's their likely philosophical stance?
Research Paradigm: A research paradigm is a
that guides researchers in conducting their studies. It encompasses the underlying
about how research should be conducted, including
about reality/nature of being/existence (ontology), knowledge (epistemology), and values(ethics/morals) (axiology).
Why Research Paradigm? Research paradigms provide a coherent
Ensure the research is grounded in a philosophical context.
If your research focuses on the lived experiences of software developers, which paradigm might be most relevant?
; focuses on understanding the context and meaning of social phenomena.
Blends different methodologies and focuses on
Are these the only research philosophy? Compare and contrast them
and rationale of the research process. It includes the methods used to collect and analyze data, and is
Interviews, focus groups, and content analysis.
first develop a theory and hypothesis and then design a research strategy to test the hypothesis
first collect data and then develop theory as a result of the data analysis
Integration of Deduction and Induction forms the scientific method
begins with general statements (premises) and, through logical argument, comes to a specific conclusion.
often used for generating our hypotheses in research
When we are using deductive reasoning, your conclusion will be correct if all the statements you say is correct.
All students in this class play guitar
Selam is the student of this class
starts from specific observations then develops a general conclusion from them.
general conclusions based on many specific observations
When using inductive reasoning, correct observations
won't necessarily lead you to a correct general conclusion
Every quiz has been easy, therefore the test will be easy
The teacher used PPT in the last few classes, therefore the teacher will use PPT tomorrow

contentBlocks.alt: Flowchart for deduction: If theory is true -> X will occur. Test X. If X does occur -> theory supported. If X does not occur -> theory challenged.

caption.text: Deductive process of testing a theory.

content.text: If X does not occur, is the theory supported or challenged?
A hypothesis states that there is a relationship between two concepts and specifies the direction of that relationship.

contentBlocks.alt: Diagram showing 'Age' box pointing to 'Gross annual income' box.

content.text: The elements in the boxes are called
The lines between the boxes are called
are composed of concepts linked by relationships.
A positive sign shows a positive relationship, e.g. (hours of study rises, exam grades rise)
A negative sign shows a negative relationship, e.g. (Price of houses rises, demand falls)
A variable is a characteristic which has more than one category or value. e.g. ‘Age’
The assumed cause is called an
is the means by which X affects Y……..

caption.text: Job is a means by which education affect income level. Job is an intervening variable. Education is independent variable and income is dependent variable.

content.text: Which approach to select? (Deductive vs. Inductive)

Deductive: More sources; uses existing theories for framework.
Inductive: Less sources; generates new data and theories.

Deductive: Quicker to complete.
Inductive: Requires more time for data collection and analysis.

Deductive: Lower-risk strategy; builds on established theories.
Inductive: Higher risk; uncertainty in theory emergence.

Deductive: Preferred by those valuing established frameworks.
Inductive: Appeals to those interested in exploratory research.

Deductive: Favored by funders requiring structured outcomes.
Inductive: Attracts support for innovative or exploratory research.
If you have very limited time for your research, which approach, deductive or inductive, might be more practical?
Need for a clear research strategy:
Is it possible to combine approaches?
Describe each of the above research strategies. When we use them? Pros and Cons? What type of research approaches, data collection methods, and research philosophies relying on?
Research Strategies: Case study vs Survey

Case Study: A case study refers to an in-depth study in which an individual, group, or a particular situation is studied.
Survey Method: A survey refers to research where data is gathered from an entire population or a very large sample in order to comprehend the opinions on a particular matter.

Case Study: Case studies are used in qualitative research.
Survey Method: Surveys are mostly used in quantitative research.

Case Study: Case studies produce rich in depth data.
Survey Method: Surveys produce numerical data.

Case Study: For a case study, a relatively small population is chosen. This can vary from a few individuals to
Survey Method: For a survey, a large population can be used as the sample.
There are two major advantages to employing multi-methods in the same study.
Different methods can be used for different purposes in a study.
Cross-Sectional Study : Data collected at one point in time.
Example : Survey of developer tool usage today.
Pros/ Quick, inexpensive, Good for broad overview
Cons:Can't establish cause-effect, Doesn't show change over time
Longitudinal Study : Data collected at multiple points in time from the same subjects.
Example : Tracking project defect density monthly for a year.
Pros/ Tracks change over time, Stronger causal inferences
Cons: - More expensive, time-consuming, - Potential for attrition
Key Difference: Cross-sectional = "Snapshot"; Longitudinal = "Movie". Choice depends on whether you need to understand change over time.

Type & Use: Quant/Qual: Broad opinions, large groups.
Pros: Efficient, standardized, anonymous.
Cons: Superficial, bias, low response.

Type & Use: Qual: In-depth understanding, individual perspectives.
Pros: Deep insights, flexible, rapport.
Cons: Time-consuming, interviewer bias, generalization issues.

Type & Use: Qual/Quant: Real-world behavior, usability.
Pros: Direct, contextual, unexpected events.
Cons: Hawthorne effect, subjective, limited scope.
Automated Collection (Logging, Code Analysis, Performance Monitoring)

Type & Use: Quant: Performance, user behavior, code characteristics.
Pros: Objective, high volume, minimal effort.
Cons: Setup, overhead, privacy concerns.

Type & Use: Quant/Qual: Historical data, trends, code evolution.
Pros: Available data, historical, large scale.
Cons: Incomplete data, context may be missing.

Type & Use: Quant: Cause-effect, intervention impact.
Pros: Strong causality, high internal validity (true exp).
Cons: Artificiality, ethical concerns, cost, external validity.

Type & Use: Quant/Qual: System requirements, design, testing.
Pros: Non-intrusive, readily available information.
Cons: Incompleteness, plans vs. reality.
A theoretical framework is a structure that
through which to interpret findings and
If the research is about the impact of social media on youth mental health, the theoretical framework might include theories such as:
How behaviors are learned through observing others on social media.
How exposure to differing views on social media can affect mental health.
? The theoretical framework provides a ______ for interpreting your findings.
What theories available in software engineering? SDLC models, Object-Oriented Theory, SQA theory,..
A conceptual framework is closely related to a theoretical framework but focuses
It visually represents the relationships among various concepts and variables and serves as a guide for the research process.
A conceptual framework for the research in previous slide might visually represent:
Social media usage (time spent, type of content).
Indicators of mental health (anxiety levels, self-esteem).
? A conceptual framework shows the relationships between what?

contentBlocks.alt: Comparison: Conceptual Research (related to abstract ideas/concepts, no practical experiments, philosophical) vs Empirical Research (conclusions from verifiable evidence/observation/experience, observable/measurable phenomena, quantitative/qualitative studies).

content.text: Empirical research is a systematic investigation that seeks to obtain knowledge through
direct or indirect observation and experimentation.
and focuses on collecting data to answer specific research questions or hypotheses.
? Is gathering data from GitHub repositories conceptual or empirical research?
Patterns and theories developed for understanding
Sample size is not a concern; "informal rich” sample
Searches which bugs are worth counting

content.text: Research Strategies: Survey (highlighted in red on slide)
Nature of the data: Mixed Qual/Quants
Research Approaches: (Not specified for Inductive/Deductive in this column)
Research Strategies: Case Study (highlighted in red on slide)
Time Horizon: (Not specified for Cross Section/Longitudinal in this column)
Research Approaches - Case study: Impact of Code Reviews on Software Quality
Effect of code reviews on reducing defects in software development

Independent: Frequency of code reviews, Experience level of developers
Dependent: Number of defects in released software
Highly Structured: Clear implementation stages and standardized metrics for evaluating quality
Researcher Independence: Researcher is separate from the development team to avoid bias
Operationalization: Define "defects" and "code reviews" in measurable terms
Break down software quality into specific metrics (e.g., defect density, customer feedback)
Select multiple projects from different teams to ensure robust sample size
Systematic approach enables objective assessment of the relationship between code reviews and software quality, allowing for broader generalization.

summary.text: This chapter provided an in-depth look at research methodology, covering philosophical underpinnings (ontology, epistemology), the research onion model, paradigms (positivism, interpretivism), approaches (deductive, inductive), various strategies, data collection methods, and the distinction between theoretical, conceptual, and empirical research.
